An Archeologist job              

                                           by: Brenna Lindsey

 

 

  The job of an archeologist is an exciting job but can be tricky at times as well. Archeologist have a very unique job as well, they dig up artifacts left from historical times. They also help discover artifacts that have never been found before, as well as things we know of but have no clue where to look for them at.

   

      An archeologist has many different tools that are available to them when excavating, they have a pick and shovel most digs often start with these two items. They are used to dig into the earth, fairly close to artifacts. They also have a whisk and Dustpan these are used to brush dirt from artifacts and clear it away from the dig site. They can also use a knife the knife is used for scraping dirt away from the ground and artifacts. Wheelbarrows are also available to archeologist, a wheelbarrow moves items from one place to another place that are to fragile to carry or it can be used to carry dirt away from the excavation site.

 

                 Archeologist also have lots of ways to use technology to help them as well. Computers can find were objects are in the ground by digitally scanning the area, computers can also tell how deep some artifacts might be berried in the ground. Computers can also tell where objects are and where to dig to find them at. Also computers can also tell an archeologist were to start digging.

 

                  

                             Archeologist also have to be very careful when working on a dig site mainly because they could skip artifacts and or break artifacts. Archeologist have to use there special tools very carefully to insure they find as much artifacts and objects they can. Archeologist also have to be very careful with what tool they use for excavating. They have to use a different tool for each different type of soil.
 

 

                Archeologist have a tough job that can be exciting, scary and fun at the same time. Many Archeologist have helped discover things of the past and things no one had ever knew existed. That's why today we can thank archeologist all over for helping us to discover some of the worlds most famous artifacts and pieces of history. We can also thank archeologist for the help they give and all the artifacts and treasures they have found for all the museums all over the world. Archeologist are a great help to the world and without them we would not have all the knowledge we have today, we would not have hardly any of the artifacts in museums or in galleries, nor would we have the knowledge on objects like dinosaurs and fossils without the help of archeologist.

Digging for History Informational Performance Task

   By Tyler

April 11, 2013

 

        If there are people who think that archeologist's jobs are not important, then they are very wrong. There are very few jobs in the world that are more important than an archeologist's job. One reason an archeologist's job is so important because we would barely know anything about our past if there were no archeologists. We might be able to find little pieces of evidence, but we would still only know little bits of evidence about our past. One of the many things that we might not know about in our history if we didn't have archeologist's are what happened to George Washington as a child, because George Washington didn't write down what happened in his childhood (at least that we haven't found yet) archeologist's first had to know where George Washington grew up as a kid to find evidence of his childhood. Then they had to do lots of digging to find evidence.

 

        An archeologist's job is very hard. One reason an archeologist's job is very hard is that when they are digging for artifacts, they can only dig tiny bits of soil at a time because the artifacts would probably be very fragile because it is from a while ago and if they dig too much soil at one time, they might accidentally break the artifact with the shovel and then we might not know a part of our past because the evidence for it happening would be broken. Another reason archeologists job is hard is because they have to use shovels that can only dig up a small part of the soil, it can sometimes take day's to dig up 25 square inches of sand! That is a very long time for that amount of soil. If I had to do that job, I would start getting very bored and frustrated because it would take forever to dig up a tiny part of soil that might not even have any artifacts in it. One other reason an archeologist's job is very hard is for the archeologist's that work in the lab. They can study one artifact for days. That is a long time to focus on one object. Again if I had that job I would start getting very frustrated.

 

        An archeologist has to have a tremendous amount of patience if they want to do their job well. Archeologists have a shovel that can dig a lot of sand in one dig. If the archeologist did not have very much patience, then they could take that shovel out and start digging with that shovel and if they did do that, then they would probably break a lot of the evidence and the evidence can't just appear in that spot again so the evidence would be broken and we might never know about a really important part of history. Also, the archeologist's that work in the lab have to have a lot of patience because if they didn't have a lot of patience, then they could just say that they studied every little detail of the artifact even if they didn't and again we might not know about a very important part of our history. If the people who carry the artifacts that are too heavy to carry by hand don't have patience, when they start taking the heavy artifacts away, they might want to speed up the process by running to wherever they have to take it. If they run with the wheelbarrow full of artifacts, two things might happen. One thing that might happen is that the artifacts could fall out of the wheelbarrow and break. Another thing that could happen is that the archeologist could drop the wheelbarrow with the artifacts inside of it. If either of the things happen the artifacts will probably break because the artifacts are from a long time ago and are very fragile. Those are a few reasons why an archeologist has to have a lot of patience.

     First thing you need to know is what the job of an archeologist is. The job of an archeologist is to study the past.

 

     The second thing you need to know is what tools do they use. The tools are a pick, shovel, whisk and dustpan, a knife, wheelbarrow, skim shovel and a trowel. They use a pick and a shovel because most digs start with these two tools. Used to dig into the earth, close to artifacts. A whisk and dustpan used to brush dirt off the artifacts and clear away the dirt from the excavation site. They use a knife for careful digging and to scrape dirt from around the artifacts. They use a wheelbarrow to move an item from one place to another. They use a skim shovel to carefully remove a thin layer of dirt away from the excavation site. They use a trowel to scrape and cut view the different layers of soil.

 

     That is all you need to know about archeologists.

Being an Archeologist is very hard work.  An Archeologist is a person that digs up bones from prehistoric animals from dinosaurs to wooly mammoths.  When they finish digging up the animals bones they ship them to a museum, and from there they put them together like a really big puzzle and put them on display in the museum.  They yous many tools to help them dig up the bones like.

 

Pick axe and shovel- Most digs start with these two tools.  Used to dig into the earth, close to the artifacts.

 

Whisk and Dustpan-Used to brush dirt off the artifacts and clear away dirt from the excavation site.

 

Knife- Used for careful digging and to scrape dirt from around artifacts.

 

Wheelbarrow- Used to move items from one place to another or to carry dirt away from the excavation site.

 

Skim shovel- A shovel with a flat edge used to carefully remove a thin layer of soil with each scoop.

 

Trowel- Probably the most common tool in archeology. Used to scrape and cut to view the

different layers of soil.

 

As you can see there are many tools to help them find the artifacts.  Archeologist are very important in life  because if we didn't have them we wouldn't know as much as we do if they didn't dig them up and tell us about the bones and what animal it was.  The museums wouldn't

have as much cool dinosaur bone if there weren't any archeologists.  In conclusion, archeologists

are more important in life than we ever imagined.

What are do archeologists do? Archeologists study objects from the past. The article "Finding Fort James," talks about how archeologists found artifacts at Jamestown island. The archeologists were working on discovering the secrets of James Fort in Jamestown, Virginia. For over 200 years, people had thought that James Fort had been washed away by a river. Some discoveries say that the fort might still be around.

      The James Fort was built in 1607. Most people believed that James Fort was built near a river. The settlers that came from England went there because it was easier to dock their ships there and the fort was located further away so it probably gave the settlers more protection from their enemies and their ships. The archeologists uncovered armor and weapons. They also discovered the floors of buildings. over a 100 years later, archeologists made a group effort to find the exact spot where the fort was built

      The National Park Service led a 5 year study to figure out how the land was used. The people doing the study used computer mapping software to make an image of the area. Finally, that's when they found James Fort. The archeologists found out where the walls used to be and that the fort would be shaped like a triangle. They made maps and they found out that the fort went all the way til the river. The archeologists also found cellars, dozens of burial sites, and ten buildings all within the border of the fort.

      The article "Digging up George Washington's Past," is about archeologists working at George Washington's house. George Washington's home is also known as Ferry Farm for over 12,000 years. It's not surprising that George Washington's father, Augustine Washington, moved his family there. Nobody exactly knew where George Washington's home was located since the real building was gone. Still archeologists believed that the stone base under the house was still there. They started digging in 2003, and it took over a year but they finally found it. The first buildings they found were the kitchen, slave quarters, and storage houses. They also found the main farmhouse a few years later. There were at least 4 houses that had been built on the Ferry Farm land so they need to find concrete proof that that was George Washington's farmhouse.

     The archeologists found out that the Washington's had a fire in their house. The diggers found pieces of burnt pottery and they also found part of a clay pipe. The archeologists knew that George Washington smoked clay pipes, so this gives more proof that that was the right house.

     These are the kind of jobs archeologists do. They find nearly 1 million objects each year. For example, pottery, tools, coins, and even metal toys for children. Objects from the past helps us understand how people lived in the past. It is more than exciting to discover objects that were regularly used by people who lived hundreds of years ago. It also ties us to the people who first started the American colonies.

Archeologists And What They Do

          By: Nicholas Manske

 

           I bet you would think of Indiana Jones if you thought about an archeologist. First of all Indiana Jones is not your typical Archeologist. Second of all he was not real. Archeologist's are people who discover the lost and mysterious, treasures of history. Archeologist's have found some of the most historic places in history such, as the mythical city of troy. Howard Carter was a famous archeologist who found the tomb of king Tut. The discovery was amazing because most of the tombs in kings valley where robbed by grave robbers but, king Tut's tomb was completely untouched.Archeologist's find history and that is what they do for a living.

 

           An Archeologist's job dig up the past, basically. The common tools for an Archeologist is an pickaxe, a shovel, a whisk and dustpan, a knife, a wheelbarrow, a skim shovel, a Trowel, and a whip "Just Kidding". Sorry for the Indiana Jones reference, anyways those tools have specific uses. The pickaxe and shovel are used usually to start a dig. The whisk and dustpan is used for dusting of dirt and dust delicately. The wheelbarrow is used for carrying dirt away and some times it is used for carrying artifacts away. A skim shovel is used for removing a thin layer of dirt. Trowel is the most common tool for archeologist's. It cuts away different layers of soil.

 

            In 1993 Archeologist's were looking for the seventeenth century Fort James in Jamestown, Virginia. People had thought that the fort had disappeared because they thought it was washed away by the river that was next to it. The fort was built in 1607 for a new settlement in the America's. The first discoveries of the fort were found in 1861. They had uncovered weapons and armor. Then over a hundred years later Archeologist's finally found it. The used computer mapping and drawings to find where it was. The first thing they found was the marks in the ground. Those marks are they indication of where the walls were. The fort was in a triangle shape. They soon found the stone ledges that held the cannons for the fort. Archeologists found four cellars. They found ten buildings within the perimeter of the fort. They found dozens of burial sites around the fort too. Every year nearly one million objects are taken from the site each year. Those artifacts include coins, pottery,tools and children's toys. That excavation is an example of what the Archeologist's do every day for a living.

 

            Archeologist's work hard to find history. They work hard to protect the history of the world. The things they uncover are amazing. Fort James is one of many excavations that archeologists do. Archeologist's find most of the things you can find in the museum. Archeologist's are my hero's. I want to be one when i grow up.

The Job of an Archeologist

                                                            By: Faith Henry

       The job of an archeologist is to uncover artifacts and study them. We do it every single day. I Cameron Cancha am an archeologist that is in the team that studies the artifacts after they have been uncovered, so basically I get to see what the artifacts are.

 

      One team maps the site on 3D computers that can track what is below the ground. Another team actually digs, the place they dig is called a dig. Those archeologists start with a shovel called skim shovels. Skim shovels are so small sharp and flat that they can remove thin layers of soil, one at a time. The soil that has been removed then is placed in a box with a half-inch screen at the bottom. The soil falls out and the artifacts stay in.

   

        The diggers also use a tool called a trowel that is a tool that is the most common, it is used to scrape and cut to view the different layers of soil. Troweling is the hardest process in archeology. You use small shovels, paint brushes, and wooden picks to remove dirt. It takes a lot of time and effort!

 

         Then comes the last job, my job. My team and I spend DAYS in the lab studing the objects that were found. But finally we finish. My eyes get SO tired that I almost fall asleep, but I keep on working, my team needs me and I need them!

 

         

         Well those are the different jobs of the archeologists. If you want to be one then be my guest! But it truely is a tiresome process, it takes a lot of time and effort so just be ready!

ALL ABOUT ARCHEOLOGISTS

 

 

Archeologists are people who study artifacts from the past.

 

How do Archeologists collect the objects that they will study?

 

The awnser to the question that is listed above is: The first team of  Archeologists start to dig with an object called a skim shovel. Next, the Archeologists place the dirt in a box with screen at the bottom which sifts the dirt out of the box and keeps the artifacts inside. But it is not as easy as it sounds. The skim shovels are small and flat and only pick up a small amount of dirt at a time and so it takes longer to fill the box with dirt.Then the Archeologists do something called troweling. Troweling is using paint brushes, small shovels, and wooden or metal picks to remove the dirt in and on the artifacts. Next, the Archeologists do a study and find the history of the artifact.The other team spends a few days in the lab studying the artifacts that are found.The process is very slow but to the archeologists, it is worth every minute. And that is how Archeologists do their job.

Tools for archeologists

           

                 There are many tools archeologists use for finding artifacts during an excavation. Two of the most common are the whisk and dustpan and a trowel. Tools are used for different purposes in archeology but all of them help in their own way.

 

                  First we have the whisk and dustpan. If an archeologist ever needs to clean an artifact he/she probably will use this tool. It's bristled end can brush dirt off artifacts, which can be important if there are any inscriptions on the artifact. The whisk and dustpan can also clear away any dirt from the excavation site, this is important if animals live near by. The whisk and dustpan is and always will be an important tool for any archeologists.

 

                   Finally, we have the trowel. it is probably the most common tool in archeology. Why, you might ask. the trowel is the most common because it's sharp end can cut and scrape through dirt to view different types of soil. The trowel is important because you can find many fossils in soil. Fossils are valuable after they are analyzed by an archeologist.Without the trowel, archeologists wouldn't find nearly as many fossils as they do with the trowel.

 

                    Tools are by far the most important element of archeology, two of the most important tools being the trowel and the dustpan and whisk. With these tools archeology is a lot easier. Archeology would be nothing without tools so all archeologists are thankful to have them.

Archeologists

 

 

 

 

 

     Acheologists have a very important job in history. They have discovered most of the historical articals or books you have read. Archeologists dont just have to dig up things and write about it. They have to figure out who it used to belong to, what the item is, and if it is important. But, they do much, much more. An archeologists job is tough.

 

     Archeologists have to be thinking about what they are looking at very carefully for many different reasons. One reason is because they have to see if it can be useful. But they have help by many different kinds of help, by many different things. They get help by machines, people, and their brains.      Archeologists dont just use their hands, they use many other tools. Their tools are very special and have their own special use. Some of their tools are: the pick, shovel, whisk, dustpan, knife, wheelbarrow, skim shovel, and the trowel. Archeologists use much many tools, but these are a few I can name. these tools come in handy at times. They all have their own use. The pick and shovel are used to dig into the earth, close to the artifacts. The whisk and dustpan are used to brush dirt off the artifacts and clear away dirt from the excavation site. The knife is used for careful digging and to scrape dirt from arounnd the artifacts. Also, the wheelbarrow is used to carry items from one place to another, or to carry dirt away from the excation site. Another tool is the skim shovel, it is used to carefully remove a thin layer of soil with each scoop. Now last, is the trowel. This tool is used to scrape and cut to view the different layers of soil. There is a lot of tools involved in a archeologist's job.

Finding artifacts in the past are very exiting to see, but how do they find these old artifacts? Here's how they discover it. Archeologists go to sites to look for where a well-known person used to live. Like, George Washington for example, recent discoveries at Washington's childhood home have helped archeologists know more about him as a young boy.

 

   Archeologists recently went to the Ferry Farm to discover George Washington's past and recovering about this long gone farmland. The process of digging at the Ferry farm is a careful one. Each year, many teams will work on the site. The can be up to 35 people in one team! The first team maps the area using 3D computers that can track what is underground. The information will be recorded so that the archeologists will know what it looked like before people before started digging. Another team focuses on the actual digging, and the place the team does the digging is called a dig. Those archeologists start their dig with what are called skim shovels. These shovels are so small, flat, and sharp that they can remove thin layers one at a time. Then that soil is placed in a box with a half-inched screen at the bottom. This lets the dirt fall out while the artifacts stay in. The diggers also use a process called troweling. Troweling is when archeologists use small shovels, paint brushes, and wooden picks to remove the dirt. It can take up to two weeks to dig a 25-square-foot section! And another team spends days in the lab studying the objects that are found. the whole process is slow and tiresome, but it's really worth it.

In 1994, a group of people interested in finding Fort James.For over 200 years, people thought that the fort had been washed away by a river.The fort was biult in 1607 when settlers came from England to start a new life. Most believed that James Fot was built near the river.However, objects found nearby suggested the fort was located further away.The first objects were found in 1861.Over 100 years later, a group effort to find the exact spot where the fort was built began.The National Park Service led 5 year study of the area to figure out how the land was used.The people doing the study used computer mapping software to make image of the area.That's when they finally found James Fort! The first thing thet found was a set of marks on the ground.The marks showed where the fort's walls used to be.Between all the stories they heard and read, and drawing they made, the archeologists knew that the fort would be shaped like a tringle.

 

 

 

Today, the groups find nearly 1 million objects each year. In the 1600s, peopleused to throw their trash down unused well or into a bid pit. We noe know what the settlers did to survive the difficult years when they had little food. It is exiting to discover objects that were regulary used by people who lived hundreds of years ago. It gives us a peice of our last and ties us to people who first started the American colonies.

Archeologists have an important job. To be an archeologist, you have to be patient. Finding artifacts from years and years ago is not easy, but it can be made slightly easier with the right tools.

  Most of the archeologists dig at the site where they think an artifact is. They use several tools, including the skim shovel, the trowel, and the pick and shovel. The many diggers dig through a very large area, and it can take weeks. You don't always find something though.

  As mentioned before, you must be patient when digging. There were settlers in 1607 and the first artifacts found from them were discovered about two hundred years after. You also have to study, and a lot. The National Park Service studied for five entire years just to figure out how the land was used. Sometimes, it doesn't take as long, but it usually takes a while.

  Also, you may not know whether the artifact you have found is from that time. People may have later settled in that same area and left more modern things behind, and you have mistaken it for something ancient. Or, you might just be looking in the wrong spot and not find anything at all. You might mistake something useless for something valuable, or vice versa. Archeologists have to be very careful when they examine the things they have found because it might be worth something. You never really know until you study closely.

  When a group of archeologists is lucky, they can find nearly one million artifacts each year.

This is what it is like to be an Archeologist.  It is hard work.  You would need a lot of patience.  Let's get started!

 

Archeologists are people who dig up ancient artifacts and see what they are, who they belonged to and when it was from.  It can take days to find something valuable.  Archeologists use special tools such as shovels, brushes, and picks.  They use picks to move dirt.  They use brushes to clear away dirt from the site and to clear off artifacts.

 

This is how they find artifacts.  First, they use computers to locate the artifacts.  Then, they dig up layers of the Earth's soil with a big shovel.  Then, they use smaller shovels to get to the last layer.  Next, they use the brushes to clear away the dirt on the artifact.  Lastly  they give it to the archeologist team who study it.

 

A 25-square-foot section can take up to two weeks to dig!  Finding things can be important.  They can tell us important things from history like finding George Washington's things.  They tell us about him as a child, maybe.  Or they can tell us what he liked to do for fun.  It'd be boring, but it would be worth it.

 

That is partly what it'd be like to be an Archeologist.  Maybe you'd like to be one someday.  It might actually be fun.  You could find coins, clothes, or a pipe!

The Job of an Archeologist 

                                                        

Archeologists have an important job of learning about the past. Without them we would not know much about things like what tools people used or even where they lived. They teach us about how the people survived and also how they fought enemies. It also lets us know why people made the decisions they made and what they were like.

 

How do archeologists find all that information? First, they must find the site that the place they want to find out about is on. They look for artifacts that were used at the place and when they find some they know that the place was near or where the artifacts are. Next, they use a 3D computer that track what is under ground so that the archeologists know what to look for. Then, they start digging. They are very  careful not to damage any artifacts that are under the ground so they only dig up a bit a of dirt at a time. Finally, they study the artifacts they found and decide what they mean.

 

What tools do the archeologists use? Some examples of what they use include:

 


A pick and shovel for digging
A whisk and dustpan for brushing dirt off the artifacts
A knife for careful digging and to scrape dirt off artifacts
A wheelbarrow to transport dirt and items from one place to another
A skim shovel to remove thin layers of soil
A trowel to scrape and cut to view different layers of soil

The Life of an Archeologist

An archeologist has a very hard and interesting job. Basically, they have to investigate the lives of those who lived long ago. But, they also have to have the correct items to identify what people ate, did, etc. After cleaning those items, they relate them to what they would have been used for. For an example, if an archeologist was examining the life of Native Americans in one of their ancient huts, and he/she found a rabbit skeleton, then he/she would know that Native Americans ate rabbits. They study the past, discover new things about it, and can teach others about what they've learned.

 

An archeologist studies the past in order to get information on what they are trying to discover more about. That way they already have an idea of what else they need to know. Then, they head out to explore more about the subject. It might not be as fun to just learn about something, but it pays off when archeologists get to uncover artifacts and discover things about them.

 

An archeologist discovers new things while obtaining old artifacts. By finding one item, the archeologists are able to find out more things based on this "newly discovered" object's uses and relate them to what people did. As I said earlier, we could find out that Native Americans ate many rabbits, and if rabbits were extinct today, we'd know what caused that extinction. It is also very useful to learn about because we can discover the cause of things that have happened. For an example, if we didn't know why the sky is blue (even if we do), and let's say that we found out that there was some "blue chemical" released into the air because there were hints of it in crumbling caves from long ago, we could get rid of other fears that we have, like excess carbon dioxide makes it blue or some nonsense like that.

 

Lastly, archeologists can teach others about what they have learned. Obviously, they don't just find information and store it in their brains. They tell others, let's say some scientists who will then scientifically analyze that artifact and find out even more. Then those scientists will put what they learned out to the public, in a book, most of the time, to educate others. It is always good to know more about a subject because it benifits you with more knowlege. So, technically, archeologists teach the world about what they've learned.

 

Archeologists have a challenging job that benifits the rest of us. They study the past, discover new things, and can teach others about what they've learned. They have an important job in our society. They dig for history!

Archeologist

 

 

         Have you ever dug in your backyard and found something like a piece of what looks like broken glass? That may have been an artifact from long ago! This is what some people do for a living. They are archeologists.

 

         How do they do it?Archeologists use special 3-D computers to track what is underground. next they record the information. Then they go to the site where they found the artifact and then they go dig. First, they use a small, sharp, and flat tool called a skim shovel and remove each layer one at a time. Next they put the dirt they had just shoveled out and put it in a sifter so that the dirt goes out and the artifacts stay in. Diggers also use troweling to find things as well. Troweling is where people use paint brushes wooden picks and small shovels to find the artifacts. It can take up to two weeks to dig a twenty-five-square-foot hole! Then they go to the lab and examine all the different things they found. Trying to find the artifacts is very difficult, tiring, and a lot of work, but it is worth it because we find out so much about our history through the artifacts.

 

         Some tools they used include: the pick and shovel, whisk and dust pan, knife, wheelbarrow, skim shovel, and a trowel. The pick and shovel and used to start digs and tom penetrate the earth to get to the artifacts. The whisk and dustpan were used  to brush the artifact clean and clear the dirt away from he digging site. The knife was used to scrape thick layers of dirt that are on the artifact off, and to carefully dig it out. The wheelbarrow is used to move the found items and dirt to different locations. The skim shovel is used to remove a thin layer of soil at a time with its sharp flat edges. Finally, the trowel is is used to cut soil so the archeologists can see the different layers. It is probably the most common tool an archeologist uses.

         

         Archeology can give us a better understanding and more knowledge of someone and/or a time period. For instance when they found George Washington's home that he grew up in, we learned more about: him as a boy, what led him to make the decisions he had made, how people lived in colonial times, etc.

 

         In conclusion, archeologists have a hard, fascinating, long, and knowledge-gaining job. We can learn so much about history from archeologists work. I want to be an archeologist when I grow up so that I can dig up our past!

The job of an archeologist is not an easy one. You don't just get a shovel and dig until you find something. You'll need the patience, passion, and precision.

   You might have to wait a while before you start digging. And even if you do dig you might not find what you are looking for. Most archeologist have to search for decades for the artifacts they want to find. Sadly, sometimes when they do find artifacts they are entirely fragile and break within seconds. It is important to wait for things to come before you start looking like clues of its existence. Often, seeking something without patience will quickly diminish.

   You need some passion for discovery if you are going to become an archeologist! Don't just say," Oh I'm going to be rich and famous because when I am an archeologist I'll find a gigantic chocolate city!" That's not how it works. You want to be an archeologist because you are doing it for fun. It is important to think about what doing a job is really like. In life, don't look in the past or future, focus on the present.

   Precision with tools is what you also need to be an archeologist. The pick, shovel, whisk, dustpan, knife, wheelbarrow, skin shovel, trowel, and many of tools are involved with the job. If there is a ancient pot need to be dusted for futher examination and you sweep it like a madman... CRACK! It is important to be careful with everything. Generally speaking, not everyone can do everthing.

   If you have patience, passion, and precision these thing you are the man for the job!

Archeology

Archeology is the study of artifacts and digging for artifacts.  Archeologists search for many things.  They look for artifacts from certian people in history.  But they also look for all artifacts in general too.  They look for artifacts from a famous person in history's childhood.  They look for historical places and boundries too.  If they find a historic site they'll search for artifacts within that boundry.  Artifacts they find are from all times in history.  They could find artifacts from the dinosaur time to Rosa Parks' time.Once they do find an artifact they restore it.

        It takes lots of work to find an artifact.  They use lots of different tool too.  They use:


A pick and shovel
A whisk and dustpan
A knife
A wheelbarrow
A skim and shovel
And a trowel

They use a pick and shovel to simply dig into the soil.  That is how most excavations start.  The whisk and dustpan is for brushing away any loose dirt from the artifact, or taking dirt away from the site.  A knife is used to scrape the dirt off the artifact.  It is also used to dig very carefully under the soil.  The knife is used for very careful projects.  The wheelbarrow is used to carry dirt away from the excavation site.  It also carrys different items away too.  The skim shovel is used to dig a thin layer of dirt at a time.  And a trowel is used to cut and to scrape the dirt away so they can view the different layers of soil.  A trowel is probably the most common tool.

   Some of the items I read about that archeoligists have found are items from George Washington's barn and James Fort.  They have found George Wasahington's clay pipe.  they also found where his family barn used to be.  At Fort James they found armor and weapons, floors of buildings, ledges to hold cannons, eleven cellars, dozens of burial sites, ten buildings, pottery, tools, coins, metal toys for children, and where they through all their trash.  All this helps us learn things.  Thats why people are all still searching today.  That is what an archeologist does.

The job of an Archeologist is to study interesting  things .Like finding fort james  for over 200 years ,people  thought that the fort had been washed away by a river

In 1994,a group of people where interested in studing the past  to rediscover  archaeological project The project was desined  by James Fort in Jamestown, Virgina. For over 200 years,  people thought that the fort had been washed away by a river. Some discoveries in the area hinted that it might still be around. The fort was built in 1607 when settlers came from England to start a new life. Most believed that James Fort was built near the river. It was easier to dock  ships there, so it made  sense that the settlers would  choose that spot. However, objects found nearby suggested the fort was located further away. The new spot probably gave the settlers more protection from enemy ships.

 

The National Park Service led a five-year study of the area to figure out how the land was used. They knew that this would hep them decide where to look for proof of the fort. The people doing the study used computer mapping software to make an image of the area.

 

That's when they  finally found James Fort! The first thing they found was a set of marks on the ground. The marks showed where the fort's walls used to be. Between all the stories they heard and read, and drawing they made,the archeologists knew that  the fort would be shaped like a triangle. They made maps and found out that the fort stretched  all the way to the river.Then they realized there were stone ledges built over the river. The ledges were designed to hold canons.The archeologists also found eleven cellars,dozens of burial sites,and ten buildings all within the border of the fort.

 

Today, the group finds nearly 1 million objects each year.The objects include pottery, tools,coins, and even metal toys for children.In the 1600s, people used to throw their trash down an unused well or into a big pit. While digging in the area, the archeologists found the trash the settlers threw away, including the bones of animals they ate.The information learned from these objects  helps us understand how the settlers fought the Powhatan tribe that often attacked them. We also know how the settlers did to survive the difficult years when they had little food.

 

It is exciting to discover objects that were regularly used by people who lived hundreds of years ago.It gives us a piece of our past and ties us to the people who first started the American colonies.

In 1994,thier was a group of people that wanted to be studying over the past.They started the Jamestown Rediscovery Archaeological   

Project.The project was desi200 gned to discover the secrets of the James Fort in Jamestown ,Virginia.For over 200 years , people thought that the fort had been washed away by a river. Some discoveries in the area hinted that it might still be around.

 

The fort was built in 1607, when settlers came from England to start a new life.

For exaple, in the 1600s, people used to throw their trash down an unused well or into a big pit. The also know how the settlers survived when they had little food. Archiologists have been using technonlogy and hand tools to dig up the best and finest information they can find from the past. For example, the used tools like pick and shovels, Whisk and Dustpan, Knife, Wheelbarrow, Skim Shovel, and Trowel. These tools where really important.

 

Most digs start with the Pick and Shovel. It is used to dig the eatrth, colse to the artifacts. The Whisk and Dustpan is ued to brush dirt off the artifacts and clear away dirt from the excavation site. Knifes are used for carefuly diging and crapping dirt from around artifacts. The wheelbarrow was an important tool. It is used to move itmes from one place to another or to carry dirt away from the excavation site. It is ues to scrape and cut to view the different layers of soil. Archelogist are also using small shovels, paint brushes, and wooden picks to remove dirt. Archiologists are using 3D computeres that can track waht is underground. The information is recorded so that people will know how it will look when they start digging.

Archeologists

                              By: Kaila Martindale

 

 

        Archeologist are people who study objects from the past and use these objects to do the job. 1.picks 2.shovels 3.whisks               4. dustpans 5.knifes 6.wheelbarrows 7.skim shovels  and 8.trowels. There can be up to thirty-five people on a team just to find one artifact! The first team can map the area by using 3D computers that can track what is right under our feet. The information is recorded so that people will know what the item will look like before people start the actual digging.     

 

       Another team has to focus on the actual digging, and the spot the team does the digging is called "a dig". Those archeologists start their dig with skim shovels. These shovels are so small, flat, and sharp that they can remove layers of soil, one  at a time. That soil is then placed in a box with a screen at the bottom. This lets the dirt fall out well while the artifacts stay in the box.

 

     The diggers also use a process called troweling. Troweling is when archeologists use small shovels, paint brushes, and wooden picks to remove the dirt. It can take up to two weeks to dig a 25-square-foot section! Another team spends days in the lab studying the objects that are found. The whole process is slow and tiresome, but it's worth it.

 

       The discovery of Washington's house is important for many reasons. First, it gives the people of the United States a better understanding of who George Washington was before he was famous. We also begin to know why he made the decisions that he did. Another thing it does is help historians learn about the life Colonial Americans lived. All of these things are parts of our past as Americans.

 

                And that is the job of an Archeologist.

This screen allows soil to fall out while found artifacts stay in. Another tool is a whisk and dustpan, these are used to clear soil off artifacts. one tool that is a good use outdoors in general is a wheelbarrow. wheel barrows can be used to move artifacts and/or other items. they may also be used to clear dirt away from the dig.

Digging up History!

 

          Is an archeologist's job fun? Well of course it is! Here's why this is my belief: Archeologists discover a lot of artifacts and they even discover long lost places. They dig for certain things with certain tools. That's super interesting! Archeologists find bones, marks in the ground, and they even find fossils. But most of all, they dig up history.

 

         You see, archeologists discovered dinosaur bones. But they also discovered Jamestown's Fort James. The story behind the fort was that it was washed away by a river flood. But soon, archeologists discovered that it still exists. Actually, none of it was still actually there but the memories and marks in the ground showed that was exactly where the fort was. Archeologists found artifacts near the marks in the ground where the fort was so then they new that the fort was there because of the evidence. That's how archeologists rediscovered Fort James.

 

            So far, archeologist's jobs sound fun! Not only did archeologists discover artifacts and Fort James, but they discovered George Washington's childhood home. Now, Washington's home is still around...Still standing...Still active! Archeologists decided to keep the house open for visiting, so people can check out how it was like to live like a colonist. Also, they hold classes where children learn to become a junior archeologist and to solve puzzles about the colonial time period right inside and near Washington's home at the site where you can see the giant artifact, his home!

 

            The tools are most important to archeologists! If an archeologist doesn't have tools, how is he or she supposed to discover artifacts. Think about it, if archeologists don't have tools, then museums wouldn't be around today. Picks and shovels are used for digging. When digging, these are normally the ones that archeologists use first. They use whisks and dustpans, too. The whisks are for dusting off dirt and the dustpans are to collect that dust. Knives are used for scraping off the dirt and cutting the dirt to dig. Wheelbarrows are used to carry an artifact from one place to another. Skim shovels are used for removing one layer of soil every scoop. Trowels are used most commonly because in archeology, they truly are the most helpful.

 

           So, I hope everyone thinks that archeology is important to history. Archeologists truly do have an fun and important job. They sure do know how to dig up history!

Life as an Archeologist

 

           Life as an archeologist is exciting in many ways. You can dig in histroical places that aren't open to the public. You can study ancient artifacts and maybe become famous for a discovery. You will have an exciting but tiring time in the digs or the lab. Here are some things that you can experience as an archeologist.

 

           Here is how you find and study artifacts. First, a team map the area so that you can find what's underground. Next, another team called the dig does the actual digging. They start the dig with skim shovels to remove thin layers of soil one at a time. The soil is placed in a special box where there is a half-inch screen at the bottom so the dirt can fall out while the artifacts stay in. Then, the archeologists use a whisk and dustpan, small shovels, paint brusthes, and wooden picks to remove dirt. Finally, the objects are taken to the labratory to be studied.

 

         As an archeologist, you will use many different tools while you are working. The pick and shovel most commonly starts the digs. They are used to dig into the soil, close to the artifacts. The whisk and dustpan is used to brush dirt off artifacts and away from the digging site. The knife is used for careful digging and to scrape dirt from around the objects. The skim shovel is used to move a thin layer of soil with each scoop. A trowel is the most commonly used tool. Its used to scrape and cut to view the different layers of soil. The wheelbarrow is used to carry items from one place to another or to take dirt away from the excavation site.

 

         Kids, if you're intrested in becoming an archeologist when as a job when you're older, here are some suggestions. You can go to the place where George Washington's home was discovered before he became famous, Ferry Farm. You can go to their summer workshops with both indoor and outdoor activities. Kids can explore the site, experience colonial life, and become junior archeologists by signing up for classes, games, and crafts. You can even go to their website and solve puzzles about work at Ferry Farm.

 

        Being an archeologist is a nice experience. You can dig in historical places that are closely guarded, study ancient artifacts, become famous, and have fun. Don't miss your chance to become an archeologist, no matter what your age is!

Tools used by archeologists

 

Pick and Shovel: most digs start with these two tools.Used to dig into the Earth, close to the artifacts.

Whisk and Dustpan: Used to brush dirt off the artifacts and clear away dirt from the excavation site.

Knife: Used for careful digging and to scrape dirt around the artifacts.
Wheelbarrow: Used to move items from one place to another or to carry dirt away from the excavation site.

Skim Shovel:A shovel with a flat edge used to carefully remove a thin layer of soil with each scoop.

Trowel: Probably the most common tool in archeology. Used to scrapeand cut to view the different layers of soil.

In 1994, some people interested in the past started the Jamestown Rediscovery Archaeological Project or JRAP for short.The project was started to discover the secrets of  Jamestown. 2.     For over two hundred years people thought the fort was washed away by a river.Some discoveries in the area hinted that it might still be around                                                                             3.   The fort was built in 1607 when settlers came from England to start a new life.Most believe that James fort was built next to a river.It was easier to dock ships there,so it made more sense that the settlers would pick that spot.

Archeologists

 

Archeologists are scientists who study objects from times in the past and discover things that no one has found before. Sometimes archeologists will study some historical sites from where some past presidents have lived. Just like where George Washington lived when he was a boy before he became president. Or maybe you could explore a fort like Fort James! Being an archeologists could be a fun job for a lot of people.

 

Archeologists have to use many tools. Some examples are: a pick and shovel, a whisk and dustpan, a knife, a wheelbarrow, a skim shovel, and a trowel. A pick and shovel are used for digging into the Earth and getting close to artifacts. A whisk and dustpan are used for brushing dirt of the artifact  and clear away dirt from the site. A knife is used for for careful digging and to scrape dirt away from around the object. The other objects are used for different things too. Those are just some examples.

 

Finding the things that archeologists find at the location has a long process behind it. Especially the project at George Washington's house. Their process is a very careful one. Each year they have A LOT of teams work on the site. There can be up to as many as 35 people on a team! Now that is a lot! The first team will map the area using a 3D computer, that can track what is underground. The information is recorded  so that the people on the teams know what it looks like underground before they start digging.One of the other teams that are on the project will focus on the actual digging. The place where the actual digging is done is called a dig. Well that makes sense!

 

Once they have finished digging up the soil, it is placed in a box with a half-inch screen at the bottom. This will let all the dirt fall out while artifacts stay in. The diggers use a process called troweling. Troweling is when archeologists use small shovels, paint brushes, and wooden picks to remove dirt. It could take up to 2 weeks to dig up a 25-square-foot section! Then one more team spends DAYS in the lab studying the artifacts that were found. The whole process is slow and not so fun, but it is totally worth it.

 

As you see, being an archeologist is hard work. Even though it seems hard, I bet you would still want to be one! To find more information go to:

The Job of an Archeologist

                                     By; Ellie Villalta

                         

          This report is about the job of an archeologist on what they do, how they do it, and what tools they use.

        An archeologist is a person who study's objects from the past. Archeologists are sorted into teams, there can be up to 35 people on a team! The first team maps the area using 3D computers that can track what is underground. The information is recorded so that people will know what it looked like before people started digging. Another team focuses on the actual digging, and the place the team does the digging is called a dig. Those archeologists start to dig with what are called skim shovels. These shovels are so small, flat, and sharp that they can remove thin layers of soil, one at a time. That soil is then placed in a box with a half-inch screen at the bottom. This lets the dirt fall out while the artifacts stay in. The diggers also use a process called troweling. Trowling is when archeologists use small shovels, paint brushes, and wooden picks to remove dirt. It can take up to two weeks to dig a 25-square-foot section! Another team spends days in the lab studying the objects that are found. The whole process is slow and tiresome, but it's worth it.

Archeologist's Work

 

 

          An archeologist's job is to study artifacts from the past. They find the artifacts by doing a dig. A dig is where archeologists go to a site and use computers that make a 3-D image that shows a picture of what is under ground. Once they find the spot where the artifact is they will Start digging.

 

          To start a dig they get into teams of about 35. One team gets the 3-D image ready and the other team digs. Some digs are really long, like the Ferry Farm Dig. Ferry Farm is where George Washington lived. In the Ferry Farm Dig they found a clay pipe witch George Washington used to smoke.

 

          Another major dig was the James Fort Dig. This dig was to find James Fort. Before they started the dig people thought that the fort got washed away. But as they started to dig they found that the fort stretched miles out from the river. They found signs of the forts walls which was one of the clues that told them that the fort stretched out so far.

 

          Some tools used for an archeological dig are:

 


Pick and shovel

Most digs start with this tool. Used to get further into the soil and closer to the artifacts.

 


Skim shovel

Used to carefully remove a thin layer of soil.

 


Whisk and dustpan

This tool is used to clear away soil from above or an an artifact.

 


Knife

Used to carefully remove dirt from around the artifact.

 


Wheel barrow

Used to move dirt and artifacts around.

 


Trowel

This tool is probably the most common tool used in archeological digs, used to scrape and cut through the soil to see the different layers.

 

          To review an archeologist is a person who studies artifacts from the past. A dig is when people dig to find artifacts. To start a dig they split into two teams and use a computer to get an image of what is in the ground. to finish there are seven main tools used.

WHISK AND DUSTPAN

                                          Used to brush off dirt off the artifacts and clear away dirt from the excavation site.

 

KNIFE

            Used to careful digging and to scrape dirt from around the artifacts.

 

WHEELBARROW

                               Used to move items from one place to another or to carry dirt away away from the excavation site.

 

SKIM SHOVEL

Archeologists, the name for scientists who study objects from the past, uncovered armor and weapons. They also discovered the floors of buildings. Over 100 years later, a group effort to find the exact spot where the fort was began.

 

 

People have lived on the land known as Ferry Farm for over 12,000 years. Its location makes it a perfect place to build a home. Therefore, it's not surprising that George Washington's father, Augustine Washington, moved his family there. George was just six years old at the time.

 

No one knew exactly where the Wahington home was located since the actual building was long gone. However, archeologists believed that the stone base under the house was still there. They started digging in 2003. It took over a year, but they finally found it. The first buildings they found were the kitchen, slave quarters, and storage houses. They found the main farmhouse a few years later.

 

How do the archeologists find all these things that were in Washington's house all those years ago? The process of digging at the Ferry Farm is a careful one. Each year, many teams will work on the site. There can be up to 35 people on a team! The first team maps the area using 3D computers that can track what is underground. The information is recorded so that people will know what it looked like before people started igging. Another team focuses on the actual digging, and the place the team does the dissing is called a dig. Those archeologists start their dig with what are called skim shovels. These shovels are so small, flat, and sharp that they can remove thin layers of soil, one at a time. That soil is then placed in a box with a half-inch screen at the bottom. This lets the dirt fall out while the artifacts stay in. The diggers also use a process called troweling.

 

Troweling is when archeologists use small shovels, paint brushes, and wooden picks to remove dirt. it can take up to two weeks to dig a 25-square-foot section! Another team spends days in the lab studying the objects that are found. The whole process is slow and tiresome, but it's worth it.

 

The discovery of Washington's home is important for many reasons. First it gives the citizens of the United States a better understading of who George Washington was before he became famous. We also being to know why he made the decisions he did. Another thing it does is help historians learn about the type of life Colonial Americans lived. All of these things are key parts of our past as Americans.

They researched the shapes of forts and other important location hints. Other people have found pottery, coins, tools, and toy like objects since the time they had found the outlines.

It took them a long time, but they eventually found the kitchen, slave room, storage rooms, and the farmhouse. They used a mix of different tools to excavate he area.

 

  Archeologists use many different tools for many different uses. They first use the skim shovel to remove layers of dirt easily, and then they use trowels and the whisk and dustpan to carefully remove the artifacts.

Digging it Up

 

 

 

    Some people think that a job of a archeologist is just digging up dirt and find important stuff, like you could do it in your very own backyard.  But it's not as simple as it looks! In this essay you will read about the process of a job of a archeologist, it will include tools, artifacts, and locations where they found our first president's house!

 

   There are many teams of archeologists.  The first team maps the area using 3D computers that can track whatever is underground.  The information is recorded so that other people can use the information to locate where to dig.  The second team focuses on digging, that place where they would be digging is called a dig.  After they dig up all the artifacts such as pottery, clay, metal toys, even gold! The third team would take them to the lab and examine them.  It is a very big process.

 

    But how would you do all this? Well the archeologists have special help by their tools.  Here in this paragraph you will get to read about these tools.  When they dig up all the artifacts, they use a trowel which is most likely to be the most common tool in archeology, it is used to scrape and cut to view the different layers of soil.  They also use a skim shovel which has a flat edge used to remove a thin layer of soil with each scoop.  If you find dirt on a artifact you would use whisk and dustpan or a knife to scrape dirt around the artifacts.  To carry the artifacts to the lab you could use a wheelbarrow.

 

   That is a job of a archeologist, you could be a archeologist someday.  You could start in your own backyard.  Just follow these steps and use the proper tools!

        What does archeologists study? Why, anything you can dig up from the ground, they study. Fossils were found by them. We know that dinosaurs once roamed Earth because they discovered them.

         Don't think this is an easy job, because it isn't. It involves hours and hours of digging, sometimes just to find a pile of dirt. But don't think it isn't a fun job, because it is. You might discover a new species that was extinct! The possibilities are endless!

         Here are some things you probably need to know if you want to become an archeologist:


Patience-You won't find something in a day.
Teamwork- You can't dig, take pictures, and wheel artifacts all at the same time!
Science-after all, an archeologist is a type of scientist!
Math-measuring bones, finding area, all of this plus more is what you will need to do math-wise.

        Some tools an archeologist uses are:


Shovel (we all know what that is)
Picks (much bigger than toothpicks)
Knife (not the kitchen ones your mom uses)
Wheelbarrow (not to ride in)
Skim Shovel (Not skim milk. Skim meaning "to remove small surface")
Trowel (midget shovel you probably used when you were gardening as a kid)

         Did you always enjoy playing in the garden or sandbox, hiding objects and digging them up again? Well, it sounds like the archeologist job is good for you!

An archeologists job is to study objects from the past.  Most archeologists are interested in the study of history.  Archeologists once discovered James Fort in Jamestown, Virginia.  Their job was to dig up and discover objects from the past.  Once they do that they study the objects.  Today the group finds nearly 1 million objects each year.

 

           Archeologists have helped historians know more about Washington as a boy because of recent discoveries at Washington's childhood home.  They have found lots of Washington's house by digging them up.  They know it's his house because they found clay pipes that he smoked.  Also they found burnt pottery and records say that Washington had a fireplace.  That means that there had been a fire that occured.

 

           Archeologists used many tools during their digs.  They helped them with many things.  They start digs using apick and shovel.  They help archeologists dig into the earth close to the artifacts.  A skim shovel is used for removing thin layers of soil.  When you are done using the skim shovel, you can use a whisk and dustpan to brush off the extra dirt.  If you find objects you can use a wheelbarrow to move the objects from place to place.  A trowel is the most common tool.  it scrapes and cuts to view the different layers of soil.  As you can see an archeologist's job isn't allways fun.

Sweat runs down my face as I dig my shovel into the Earth once again. Today is a very hot day and I am sweating like crazy, but i work through it. I am digging at Ferry Farm trying to find some information about George Washington's past. I am about 30 feet deep into the Earth and my shovel hits something.

     I yell for my boss Logan, "Logan, come here! I think i found something! Come quick and bring the whisk!". Logan comes a few seconds later and he brought me the whisk. "What did you find?", he asked. "I... I don't know exactly", I said. I brush some dirt out of my way with my whisk and I tell Logan, " I think it might be a piece of burnt pottery. Can you go get me the trowel please?". "Sure. i will be right back.", he reply's.

     When Logan returns with the trowel he also brings me a water. " Here is the trowel. I brought you a water also.", he says.

I reply back, " Thanks.". I take a sip of water and grab my trowel. I find where the two sides of the pottery is and start digging under it on the right side of the piece.

      After about 5 minuets i get the burnt pottery out of the dirt. I scrape some dirt off with my whisk. I can now see what was on he pot. It looked like it was a family standing in the middle of a huge empty field filled with growing flowers. Logan snatched it out of my hand and said " Great work Riley. After 3 weeks of digging you are the first person that found something. Go ahead and take the rest of the week off. You need it.". I grin and say "Thank you". Logan nods and walks away with the pottery in his pocket. I climb up and out of my hole and walk home.

        I take a drink of my water and turn he corner, climb up the wooden steps into my cool house. I lay down on my couch and fall asleep.

The Job of an Archeologist

 

 

 

An archeologist has a very important job. Their job is to dig up artifacts from the past, so we can learn about history. A lot of archeologists dig to solve mysteries, like when a group of archeologists found Fort James.

 

Archeologists wanted to see if they could uncover anything from Fort James. In 1861, the first artifacts were found. They discovered armor and weapons. They also uncovered the floors of buildings. After about 100 years a group effort tried to find the exact spot where Fort James was built. After that, The National Park Service led a 5 year study of the area. They wanted to figure out how the land was used. People used computer mapping software, to create an image of the area. Then they finally found James Fort! A set of marks on the ground was the first thing that they found. The marks showed where the fort's walls used to be. Because of all the stories they had heard and the drawings they had made, archeologists knew that the fort was shaped like a triangle.

 

Other times, archeologists dig to find out how people lived a long time ago. Many archeologists wanted to find out more about George Washington. So, they decided to figure out where he lived, and dig up some things from his past.

 

On Ferry Farm, people have been living there for over 12,000 years. It's a perfect place to build a home. It's not surprising that George Washington's father moved his family there, when George was only 6 years old. George's house was long gone, so no one knew where his actual house was loacated. But archeologists belived that the stone base under the house was still there. In 2003 they started digging. They finally found it, but it took over a year. The kitchen, slave quarters, and storage houses, were the first things they found. A few years later, they found the main farmhouse. On the Ferry Farm land, at least 4 other houses, have been built. They needed to find proof that this was George Washington's farmhouse. Records show that in George Washington's house, there was a fire. Burnt pottery was found by the diggers. That probably means that a fire occured there. A clay pipe was also found there. George Washington smoked clay pipes, so there was more proof.

 

For archeologists to find all of that stuff, they need the right tools. Here are some of the tools that archeolgists use.

 

Pick and Shovel: They are used to dig into the earth, close to the artifacts.

 

Whisk and Dustpan: They are used to brush dirt off of the artifacts, and clear away dirt from the excavation site.

 

Knife: It is used for careful digging, and to scrape dirt from around the artifacts.

 

Wheelbarrow: It is used to move items form one place to another, or to carry dirt away from the excavation site.

 

Skim Shovel: It is a shovel with a flat edge used to carefully remove a thin layer of soil with each scoop.

 

Trowel: It is probaby the most common tool used in archeology. It is used to scrape and cut to view the different layers of soil.

 

Now you know more about the job of an archeologist. It is much more than just digging in the dirt. They uncover articfacts so we can learn about history.

    The tools that you are going to need if your an archeologist are a pick and a shovel, a whisk and a dustpan, a knife, a wheelbarrow, a skim shovel, and a trowel. The pick and shovel are used for digging far in to find the fossil because they are so sharp. The whisk and dustpan is used for if the artifact or fossil has dust or mud on it the whisk and dustpan takes it all off so the fossil/artifact is not dirty anymore. The knife is used for cutting around the artifact and getting all the excess mud/dirt off of the artifact. The wheelbarrow is used to carry the fossils from place to place, or to carry the dirt that the archeologists dug through. Because the skim shovel is so thin it is used to take layer by layer off without breaking the mud/dirt so if there is a fossil it doesn't break because the archeologists don't know what layer it can we on.  Lastly, the trowel is used to scrape and cut to view the different layers of mud/soil to check if they have any fossils or objects in them.

An arche?ologist is someone who studies objects from the past.  The job of an archeologist is not an easy one, but it sure is exciting.  There are different kinds of archeologists.  There are some who dig out artifacts and other items.  There are some that study the artifacts.  The people who dig use shovels, picks, whisks and trowewls to help them find and clean items. 

 

Archeologists work to fink things from the past, find out what they are, and figure out important facts from that time or about the person that had the artifact.  Sometimes, it might be very exciting to be an arceologist, but other times it is just hard work and disapointment.  Most of the time, you would have to dig with out the help of machines, and who knows if the items that you find are even real or important? 

 

Over all, archeologists are very important.  They help us understant the events that happened in our past and what it would be like to live many years ago.  Their discoveries tell us about important people and places.

The job of an archeologist

 

             An archeologist is someone who has the desire to learn about the past by, discovering new artifacts, classifying them and, every archeologist must have perseverance.  When you are in a search team you are split up in to separate groups that work together. One group does the the digging, they use many tools to accomplish this task without breaking anything. Another group classify the objects.  The last group maps the excavation site.  Being an archeologist takes lots of team work.

 

             To begin a search for answers from the past, researchers must use evidence from today to find a reasonable place to dig.  They do this by taking what they know and putting the knowledge together and getting the approximate location where the artifact is.  For example if you are trying to find your favorite toy because you lost it, you would use the information you know to find it.  Lets say you know the your little brother really likes your toy, but you never let him play with it, so based on this information you could see if your little brother has it.  archeologists also use 3D computers to map what is under them.  This is how archeologists find the approximate location of where the artifact they are trying to find is.                                                                                                                                                              

             Digging for the artifact is hard work because you can not use a big excavator to dig the hole because it might break what you are looking for.  Instead you must use tools like the pick and shovel to start your dig, a knife to scrap dirt away from your artifact, a wheelbarrow to carry items and dirt away from the excavation site, you will also use a whisk and dust pan to clean artifacts, a skim shovel is also very handy for removing thin layers of dirt, and finally the trowel which is very important because it can scrape and cut different layers of soil.  This process can take weeks, months or even years to find an object that is not fake, and is valuable.  

 

             Being an archeologist takes much perseverance, because if you do not find any thing important in your career, you will become very frustrated and you may rage quit.  All in all if you are an archeologist it is very rewarding, if you find something important, and it is a great job if you like exploring history.  This is what an archeologist does.

The artifacts that you scan will appear on your computer and then you can find out what it is.

 

Another important thing to know as an archeologist is what tools you use. There are six tools that they use. The first one is the pick and shovel. Most digging places start with these tools. They can help take away dirt around the artifact that they are currently looking at. The next tool is the whisk and dustpan. These two tools help to clean artifacts that archeologist find. Next, there is a knife. This tool is used to scrape dirt off artifacts. After that, there is the wheelbarrow. This helps archeologist move artifacts and move dirt away from the area. Also, there is the skim shovel. This strange shovel has a flat edge and is used to remove a thin layer of soil. Finally, there is the trowel. This is used to scrape ant cut to view different layers of soil.

Being an Archeologist

 

Have you ever wondered about how it would be like to find and discover new artifacts everyday? Exciting, would it be? That's exactly what an archeologist does as a job. Archaeologists find new and unique artifact in different places, send them to the study labs,  and research more about that object. If you want to know more about these amazing world-traveled artifact hunters, read on!  Archeologists are very detailed and specific in whatever they do. They can sometimes use objects as big as wheelbarrows to dig soil to tiny wood picks for chipping of soil of very fragile objects. There are a lot of steps in digging up fossils and artifacts of the past. They first have to get together and entire team, which can take up to thirty-five people!

 

  First of all, the first team maps the area using 3D that can track what is underground. The information is recorded on a piece of paper so everyone one can get a visual look about how the place was before they started to dig up the ground. Archeologists find many artifacts and materials that will show the past of the specific place. In this year, we have learned about a famous historical person named George Washington. There wasn't much information about where he lived and things about it. We wondered about what stuff and information was lying behind this historical man's childhood home. Coincidentally, we figured out that archeologists also had the same exact question! Some archeologists were digging at the dig to see if anything that was left behind was still right underneath the soil. One archeologist was digging and met a clay tube in the way. He thought about George Washington and remembered that he used clay tubes to smoke. This evidence proves that he was searching the correct place!

 

  Furthermore, archaeologists have gone all around the world studying about its history and artifacts. They gone to Egypt to study tombs, pharaohs, and much more. They go into tobs and try to find as much as they can. They sometimes will also remove the tombs and study the precious wealth the body has been kept with. If lucky, they are allowed to unwrap the body to get a more detailed view of what the past was like when they were alive. They have also visited King's Valley to discover the dinosaur fossils. Using fine and detailed marterial, they easily find the truth and information of the life before us.

 

  Being an archeologist can be hard work, but worth it. Now after learning about them, we should be thankful to them for helping us humans study the world and its past more clearly and thoughtfully. What are you waiting for, get out and start digging!

The places where archeologists usually go is in places where dinosaur bones can be found, maybe a temple where an ancient person ruled or symbols.  They also took Abraham lincoln's hat and George Washington's wig and famous people's belongings that have now passed away. The job of an archeologist is very hard and requires skill, patience, and hard work.  Those groups of archeologists were also very inerested in history and the past.  When you become an archeologist, you form a group of usually about 35 people.  While being an archeologist, you use tools such as a knife, skim shovel, trowel, wheelbarrow, whisk and dustpan, and the pick and shovel.  The knife is used for careful digging and to scrape dirt from around the artifacts.  Another tool called the skim shovel is used carefully remove a thin layer of soil with each scoop.  Also, the trowel is used to scrape and cut to view different layers of soil, and is also the most common tool in archeology.  The wheelbarrow is ued to move items from one place to another or carry dirt away from the excavation site.  One of the other tools called the whisk and dustpan, are used to brush dirt off the artifacts and clear away dirt from the excavation site.  Finally, the pick and shovel are used to dig into the earth, which is close to the artifcts.  Archeologists use those tools for the meanings above.  To discover historical places, like the Ferry Farm and James Fort, archeologists must search around an area for a long time.  That may take from 1-5 years.  Once they find the place, they call it an excavation site.  After they discover the area, they search for historicaal remains or leftover things.  Each time archeologists find a item, they put it in a 3D computer, where it shows what the place might hve looked like when it was built new.  If you would like to be an archeologist, why not?  It is an amazing job that brings back the past!  Also, it's like an adventure........an adventure of excitement!

In 1994,a group of people interested in studying the past started the Jamestown Rediscovery Archaeological Project.It was designed to dicover the secrets of James Fort of Jamestown,Virginia.for over 200 years,people thought that the fort had been washed away by a river.Some dicoveries in the area hinted that it might still be around.

 

 

 

 

     The fort was built in 1607 when settlers from England came to start a new life.Most believed James Fort was by a river.It was easier to dock ships there,so it made sense that the settlers would choose  that spot.The first object were found in 1861 by Arecheologists. they found there armor and weapons and the floors of the building.Over 100 years later,a group had effort to find the exact spot where the fort was built.

     In 1994, a group of people interested in studying the past started Jamestown Rediscovery Archeological Project.   (JRAP)  The project was used to uncover the secretes of the James Fort in Jamestown.VI.  For many years people thought that the fort had been washed away by a river.  Some discoveries gave them hints that it might be around!

 

   The first objects found were 1861. the Archeologist uncovered armor and weapons.  Over 100 years later, a group effort to find the exact spot where the fort was built began.

    

      Today the groups find one million objects a year! The objects include pottery,tools,coins,and even metal toys for children.  In the 1600s, people used  to throw their trash down an unused well or into a big pit.

Life as an Archeologist

 

  Have you ever wondered what it's like to be an archeologist? Well if you're not up for tedious work, it might not be the job for you.

    Many teams can work on a site, and there can be up to 35 people on a single team. That means if there were only three teams, there could already be more than a hundred people! However, before the digging even starts, the first team has to map out the area with 3D computers so that people after them will know what the site looked like before the digging started.

     The actual process of digging is long and back-breaking. The dig is started with small shovels that are called skim shovels. Skim shovels are extremely sharp and flat, so they are able to remove thin layers of soil, one at a time. That soil is then screened - the soil is put in a box with a screen so that the dirt falls out and the artifacts stay in .

     Another process that diggers use is troweling. Troweling archeologists use small shovels, paint brushes, and wooden picks to get rid of dirt. Troweling is extremely slow, however. It can take up to two weeks to dig a small 25-square-foot area!

     A final team spends days in the lab studying the artifacts that are found to find out what they mean and how they are important to our history.
